page.title: 17Local history of St. Agnes
page.content: In 1568 the Queen sold - among other chantry lands - a tenement, garden and stable in St. Agnes. This is believed to be "Penwennack", providing a house and stable for the Vicar and a horse. Tonkin gives this account of the church in his Manuscript: "It consists of three roofs, a small tower and spire with three bells, and when built was of a sufficient dimension to contain all the inhabitants; but they are so much increased that there is much need to enlarge the Church ... ". The design for the enlargement was approved in 1712 but nothing was done except that the writer himself built a small aisle for the use of himself and his family. In the windows of the church was formerly painted the History of the Life of St. Agnes - now only a small piece remains in the south window.
